captions.text: Hi, I’m John Green,
This is Crash Course World History

and today we’re gonna talk
about the Cold War,
which actually lasted into my lifetime,

which means that I can bore you
with stories from my past
like your grandpa does.
When I was a kid,

they made us practice hiding under our
desks in the event of a nuclear attack,
because, you know,

school desks are super good at repelling
radiation. [formica is magical stuff]
Mr. Green, Mr. Green!
Right, remember in elementary school

there was this special guest who’d defected
from the Soviet Union, and he had--

--Like this crazy Russian accent
and he kept going on and on about how--

Reagan should spit in Gorbachev’s face
instead of signing treaties with him.

And I was like, whoa dude calm down.
You’re in a room full of third graders.

And then for like months afterward
on the playground,

we’d play Reagan:Gorbachev
and spit in each other’s faces.
Those were the days.

Sometimes I forget that you’re me,
Me from the Past. [ahhh… so sweet!]

Yeah, it’s just really nice to
talk to you and feel like you’re lis—

You’re boring. Cue the intro.
[ah ha! there it is.]
[BEST]
[intro music]
[intro music]
[intro music]
[intro music]
[intro music]
[EVER!]

So the Cold War was a rivalry between the
USSR and the USA that played out globally.
We’ve tried to shy away from calling

conflicts ideological or
civilizational here on Crash Course,
but in this case,

the “clash of civilizations”
model really does apply.
Socialism,

at least as Marx constructed it,
wanted to take over the world,

and many Soviets saw themselves in a
conflict with bourgeois capitalism itself.
And the Soviets saw American

rebuilding efforts in Europe and Japan
as the U.S. trying to expand its markets,
which, by the way,
is exactly what we were doing.

So the U.S. feared that the USSR
wanted to destroy democratic
and capitalist institutions.

And the Soviets feared that the US
wanted to use its money and power

to dominate Europe and eventually
destroy the Soviet system.
And both parties were right to be worried.

It’s not paranoia if they really are out
to
get you. [tinfoil hats, always in season]
Now of course we’ve seen a lot of

geopolitical struggles between major
world powers here on Crash Course,

but this time there was
the special added bonus

that war could lead to the
destruction of the human species.
That was new for world history,

and it’s worth remembering: It’s still
new.

Here’s the period of time
we’ve discussed on Crash Course.
And this is how long we’ve had

the technological capability
to exterminate ourselves.
So that’s worrisome.
Immediately after World War II,

the Soviets created a sphere
of influence in eastern Europe,

dominating the countries where
the Red Army had pushed back the Nazis,

which is why Winston Churchill
famously said in 1946

that an “Iron Curtain” had
descended across Europe.

While the dates of the Cold War are
usually given between 1945 and 1990,

a number of historians will tell you that
it actually started during World War II.

Stalin’s distrust of the U.S.
and Britain kept growing

as they refused to invade Europe and
open up a second front against the Nazis.

And some even say that the decision to
drop the first Atomic Bombs on Japan

was motivated in part by a desire
to intimidate the Soviets.
That sort of worked, but only insofar

as it motivated the Soviets to
develop atomic bombs of their own—

they successfully tested
their first one in 1949.
From the beginning,
the U.S had the advantage because

it had more money and power and
could provide Europe protection

what with its army and
one of a kind nuclear arsenal
while Europe rebuilt.
The USSR had to rebuild itself,

and also they had the significant
disadvantage of being controlled
by noted asshat Joseph Stalin.
I will remind you, it’s not cursing

if he’s wearing an ass for a hat.
[way to hang your asshat on a technicality]
Oh, I guess it’s time for the open letter.

[professionally propels toward prop like
a perfectly poised & practiced projectile]
An Open Letter to Joseph Stalin.
But first,

let’s see what’s in
the secret compartment today.
Oh, it’s silly putty.

Silly putty:
the thing that won the Cold War.
[gotta be a Reagan joke in there somewhere]

This is exactly the kind
of useless consumer good

that would never have been
produced in the Soviet Union.

And it is because we had
so much more consumer spending,

on stuff like silly putty,
that we won the Cold War.
Go team!
Dear Joseph Stalin,
You really sucked.

There was a great moment in your life,
at your first wife’s funeral,

when you said,
“I don’t think I shall ever love again.”
And then later,

you had that wife’s whole family killed.
[solid case for NOT putting a ring on it]

Putting aside the fact that you’re
responsible for tens of millions of deaths,

I don’t like you because of the
way that you treated your son, Yakov.
I mean, you were really mean to him
and then he shot himself and he didn’t die

and you said,
“He can’t even shoot straight.”

And then later,
when he was captured during World War II,

you had a chance to exchange
prisoners for him, but you declined.
And then he died in a prison camp.

You were a terrible leader, a terrible
person, and a terrible father.

Best wishes,
John Green
Alright, let’s go to the Thought Bubble.

Europe was the first battleground
of the Cold War, especially Germany,
which was divided into 2 parts

with the former capital, Berlin,
also divided into 2 parts.

and yes, I know the western part was
divided into smaller occupation zones,
but I’m simplifying.

In 1948,
the Soviets tried to cut off West Berlin,

by closing the main road that led into the
city, but the Berlin airlift stopped them.

And then in 1961, the Soviets
tried again and this time they were

much more successful building
a wall around West Berlin,

although it’s worth noting that
the thing was up for less than 30 years.
I mean,

Meatloaf’s career has lasted longer than
the Berlin Wall did.[Oh y-- NOOO!!]

The U.S. response to the Soviets
was a policy called containment;

it basically involved
stopping the spread of communism

by standing up to the Soviets
wherever they seemed to want to expand.

In Europe
this meant spending a lot of money.

First the Marshall Plan spent
$13 billion on re-building western Europe

with grants and credits that Europeans
would spend on American consumer goods
and on construction.

Capitalism’s cheap food and
plentiful stuff, it was hoped,
would stop the spread of communism.

The US also tried to slow the
spread of communism by founding NATO

and with CIA interventions in elections
[looked better on paper]
where communists had a chance, as in Italy.

But despite all the great spy novels
and shaken not stirred martinis,
the Cold War never did heat up in Europe.

Probably the most important
part of the Cold War

that people just don’t remember these days
is the nuclear arms race.
Both sides developed nuclear arsenals,

the Soviets initially with the help
of spies who stole American secrets.
Eventually the nuclear arsenals were so big

that the U.S. and USSR agreed on
a strategy appropriately called MAD,

which stood for
“mutually assured destruction.”
Thanks Thought Bubble.
And yes, nuclear weapons were, and are,

capable of destroying
humanity many times over.
[regardless of Iran's access to Photoshop]

But only once or twice
did we get close to nuclear war:

during the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis
and then again in 1983,

when we forgot to give the Russians the
heads up that we were doing some war games,

which made it look like we had launched
a first strike.

OUR BAD!
[closer to ultimate fail than epic fail]

But even though mutually assured
destruction prevented direct conflict,

there was plenty of hot war
in the Cold War.

The Korean War saw lots of fighting
between communists and capitalists,
as did the Vietnam War.

I mean, these days we remember
“the domino effect” as silly paranoia,

but after Korea and especially
China became communist,

Vietnam’s movement toward communism
seemed very much a threat to Japan,

which the U.S. had helped re-make
into a vibrant capitalist ally.

So the US got bogged down
in one of its longest wars

while the Soviets assisted the
North Vietnamese army in the Viet Cong.

But then we paid them back by supporting
the anti-communist mujaheddin

after the Soviets invaded
Afghanistan in 1979.

Of course, as we now know,
nobody conquers Afghanistan
…unless you are the mongols.

[The tune of truly tendering terror
to tons of tearfully troubled tribes]

So after 10 disastrous years,
the Soviets finally abandoned Afghanistan.

Some of those mujahedeen later became
members of the Taliban,

though, so it’s difficult
to say that anyone won that war.
But it wasn’t just Asia:

In Nicaragua, the US supported rebels
to overthrow the leftist government;
in El Salvador,

the US bolstered authoritarian regimes that
were threatened by left-wing guerrillas.

The United States ended up supporting
a lot of awful governments,

like the one in Guatemala, which held onto
power through the use of death squads.
[like i said, looked better on paper]

Frankly, all our attempts to
stabilize governments in Latin America

led to some very unstable Latin American
governments, and quite a lot of violence.

And then there were the
luke-warm conflicts,

like The Suez Crisis where British
and French paratroopers were sent in

to try to stop Egypt from
nationalizing the Suez canal.

Or all the American covert operations
to keep various countries from
“falling” to communism.

These included the famous
CIA-engineered coup to overthrow

Iran’s democratically elected
prime minister Mohammed Mossadeq

after his government attempted
to nationalize Iran’s oil industry.

And the CIA helping Chile’s
General Augusto Pinochet overthrow

democratically elected Marxist
president Salvador Allende in 1973.

And lest we think the Americans
were the only bad guys in this,

the Soviets used force to crush
popular uprisings in Hungary in 1956
and in Czechoslovakia in 1968.

So, you may have noticed
that our discussion of the Cold War

has branched out from Europe to
include Asia, and the Middle East,
and Latin America.
And in fact,

almost every part of the globe
was involved in some way with the
planet being divided into three “worlds.”

The first world was the U.S.,
Western Europe and any place that

embraced capitalism and a more or
less democratic form of government.

The Second World was the
Soviet Union and its satellites,

mostly the Warsaw Pact nations,
China and Cuba.

The Third World was everyone else and
we don’t use this term anymore

because it lumps together a
hugely diverse range of countries.

We’ll talk more about the specific
economic and development challenges

faced by the so-called
“Third World countries,”

but the big one in terms of the Cold War,
was that neither the U.S. nor the Soviets

wanted any of these
countries to remain neutral.

Every nation was supposed to pick sides,
either capitalist or communist,
and while it seems like an easy choice now,

in the 50s and 60s,
it wasn’t nearly so clear.

I mean, for a little while, it seemed
like the Soviets might come out ahead,
at least in the Third World.

For a while, capitalism,
and especially the United States,
seemed to lose some of its luster.

The US propped up dictatorships,
had a poor civil rights record,
we sucked at women’s gymnastics.

Plus, the Soviets were the first to put
a satellite, a man, and a dog into space.
Plus, Marxists just seemed cooler,

which is why you never see
Milton Friedman t-shirts...
until now available at DFTBA.com.
I like that, Stan,
but I’m more of a centrist.
Can I get a Keynes shirt?
Yes. That, now that’s hot.
But Soviet socialism did not finally prove

to be a viable alternative
to industrial capitalism.
Over time,

state-run economies just generally
don’t fare as well as private enterprise,

and people like living in
a world where they can have more stuff.

More importantly,
Soviet policies were just bad:

collectivized agriculture stymied
production and led to famine;

suppression of dissent and
traditional cultures made people angry;

and no one likes suffering
the humiliation of driving a Yugo.
But why the Cold War ended when it did

is one of the most interesting
questions of the 20th century.

It probably wasn’t Ronald Reagan
bankrupting the Soviets,
despite what some politicians believe.

The USSR had more satellite states
that it needed to spend more to prop up
than the U.S. had to invest in its Allies.

And the Soviet system could never
keep up with economic growth in the West.
But,
probably the individual most responsible
for the end of the Cold War was

Mikhail Baryshnikov.
[Um...]
No? Mikhail Gorbachev?

Well, that’s boring.
[and far less lycra-clad]

I always thought the Soviets
danced their way to freedom.

No? It was Glasnost and Perestroika?
[not the cultural resonance of White Nights?]
Alright.
but Gorbachev’s Perestroika and Glosnost

opened up the Soviet political and economic
systems with contested local elections,

less restricted civil society groups,
less censorship,
more autonomy for the Soviet Republics,

more non-state-run businesses
and more autonomy for state-run farms.

Glasnost or “openness”
led to more information from the west
and less censorship led to a flood of

criticism as people realized how much
poorer the second world was than the first.

And one by one, often quite suddenly,
former communist states collapsed.

In Germany,
the Berlin Wall came down in 1989
[pulled down with the Gipper's own hands]

and East and West Germany
were reunited in 1990.
In Poland,

the Gdansk dockworker’s union Solidarity
turned into a mass political movement

and won 99 of the 100 seats it was
allowed to contest in the 1989 election.
Hungary held multiparty elections in 1990.

The same year, mass demonstrations
led to elections in Czechoslovakia.

In 1993, that country split up
into Slovakia and the Czech Republic,

the happiest and most mutually
beneficial divorce since Cher left Sonny.

Of course sometimes the transition away
from communism was violent and painful.
In Romania, for instance,
the communist dictator Ceaucescu

held onto power until he was tried and put
before a firing squad at the end of 1989.

And it took until 1996 for a non-communist
government to take power there.
And in Yugoslavia, well, not so great.

And in Russia,
it’s a little bit Putin-ey.
Ah! Putin.
But just twenty years later,

it’s hard to believe that the world
was once dominated by two super powers held

in check mutually assured destruction.
[sure didn't work for Harry & Voldemort]

What’s really amazing to me,
though, is that until the late 1980s,

it felt like the Cold War
was gonna go on forever.
Time seems to slow as it approaches us,
& living in the post-Cold War nuclear age,

we should remember that the past
feels distant even when it’s near,
and that the future seems assured—
even though it isn’t.

Thanks for watching.
I’ll see you next week.

[don't ask. you try & corral the talent
when they're a NYT best-selling author]

Crash Course is produced and directed
by Stan Muller.

Our script supervisor
is Meredith Danko.

Our associate producer
is Danica Johnson.

The show is written by my
high school history teacher
Raoul Meyer and myself.

And our graphics team is Thought Bubble.
[where time may be cold, but not too war-y]
Last week’s phrase of the week was

"Justin Bieber"
[Johnny Bookwriter is a full-on Belieber]

Thanks for that suggestion.
[he said, sincerely]

If you’d like to suggest
future phrases of the week,

you can do so in comments
where you can also ask questions

about today’s video that will
be answered by our team of historians.

[or fought out amongst yourselves with
varying degrees of merit and clarity]
Thanks for watching Crash Course
and as we say in my hometown,

don’t forget Folly and Desperation
Are Ofttimes Hard to Tell Apart.”
[Did you know John is a triple threat?]
Ow.

comments.author: FieryEarthquake

comments.text:
Stalin wasn't necessarily a "terrible leader". This depends on which 
aspects of his rule you focus on. You forget just how quickly USSR became 
industrialized from a rural backward country in the 1917 to an industrial 
superpower in the 1930s under Stalin's initiative. This was growth 
unprecedented in speed and scale to any state. Without this rapid 
industrialization it is unlikely USSR would have won the war in the first 
place. Recall thousands of t-34s (quantity has a quality of its own)? They 
would have been impossible without massive industrial factories. Unlike 
USA, USSR was largely destroyed during the war yet already in 1953 they had 
a first successful nuclear test. Stalin was a diligent study and a decent 
strategist, having commanded entire Red Army fronts under Lenin. The very 
reason he blundered thinking Hitler wouldn't attack USSR is because he 
could never imagine Hitler risking a war on 2 fronts, greatly 
overestimating his military intelligence. Those who say that it's the 
Soviet people and not Stalin who are responsible for victory (claiming 
Soviets won despite Stalin's blunders) have to explain why is it that the 
German people,  didn't win the war DESPITE Hitler's blunders? It's simply 
an absurd claim. One also has to realize that for every German soldier 
killed on the Western front, - approximately 9 met their death on the 
Eastern front (similar situation with technology). Eastern front (according 
to Wiki and other encyclopaedias) was 8-9 times more massive, which 
demonstrates beyond doubt that Soviet Union had a far bigger role to play 
in defeating Hitler than all of its allies put together. Compared to 
Hitler, - Stalin paid a lot more attention to his generals' assessment of 
the situation and was also a better strategist. Unlike Hitler he was a 
pragmatist and didn't believe in quick victory through superiority in 
"spirit" or ideology despite all odds, like Hitler did.

I don't at all deny that Stalin was a ruthless person in his personal life 
and in the way he ran the state. He was extremely punitive and paranoid, 
having condemned to death millions of Soviet people, many of those - on 
trumped up charges.  But that doesn't mean that he was an ineffective 
ruler, to say that, -  is to lack historical objectivity. Ivan the Terrible 
was also a bad person, and arguably so was Peter the Great but under their 
rule the Russian empire expanded in territory, gained in power and wealth 
and became an influential European player.  At the same time some of the so 
called "democratic" or "more democratic" Soviet and Russian leaders have 
brought their country nothing but ruin and poverty to its people. (like 
Yeltsin and Gorbatchev). Having said this I am not necessarily arguing that 
Russia can't possibly prosper under anything other than a tough, punitive 
authoritarian dictatorship, but, that so far such was its 
unfortunate historic tendency, - to fair poorly under a more permissive 
leadership.﻿

comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.author: John Doe

comments.text:
+Colin G Dude, why don't you read? 

*"*States may be sovereign.* The government is the particular group of 
people, the administrative bureaucracy, that controls the state apparatus 
at a given time.That is, governments are the means through which state 
power is employed."*


More particularly: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sovereign_state


*" a sovereign state is a nonphysical juridical entity that is represented 
by one centralized government that has sovereignty over a geographic 
area... It is also normally understood that a state is neither dependent on 
nor subject to any other power."*


It is that group of individuals who declare war and rule over the people 
within a country through force. They don't go to war on "behalf" of the 
country. It makes no sense whatsoever for Jewish men in 1941 Berlin to say 
"we" sent Jews to concentration camps, and killed my friends and family.
comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.text:
+Alique Williams Your definition of war is sound, I can give you that. 
However, I found something from your own source that might cause you to 
reconsider:
"A state is an organized *community* living under one government"
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_(polity)
Clear as day, the state is a separate entity of people living under a 
government, specifically, the people who live in a country. I apologize, I 
meant that *governments* declare war on behalf of countries, as states are 
simply the community that live within a country. You are correct, states, 
as in *the people who live under a government in a country*, go to war. 
Cheers!
comments.author: Colin G

comments.text:
+Colin G War is in fact defined as armed conflict between states, or 
organizations vying for control of the government or for the creation of 
their own state (I.E. civil or independence wars). The military is their 
main instrument for such.

*"Conventional warfare:* *...It is a declared war between existing states 
in which nuclear, biological, or chemical weapons are not used or only see 
limited deployment in support of conventional military goals and maneuvers*"

*"Unconventional warfare:" *...the opposite of conventional warfare, is an 
attempt to achieve military victory through acquiescence, capitulation, or 
clandestine support for one side of an existing conflict.*"

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War

*"War is a phenomenon which occurs only between political communities, 
defined as those entities which either are states or intend to become 
states (in order to allow for civil war)."*

http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/war/

And no, states don't go to war on behalf of a country they rule. Your 
definition doesn't even say that.
comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.text:
+Alique Williams"More or less"? You fail to describe what at all this can 
mean. But then again, what else can you mean, as literally every other 
thing that everyone knows defines a country, you reject. "Ultimately, it is 
a location". Your guise of ambiguity is thinner than tissue paper. You're 
trying to pretend that you actually believe that a country is more than a 
landmass, yet deny it at every term. Poor, poor show.

"States" do not engage in wars. Politicians and bureaucrats do not pick up 
rifles and go fight other politicians. They do not raise money for the war, 
produce supplies for the war, move, feed, shelter, supply or provide for 
troops. They do not fight in wars. It is the combined effort of a *COUNTRY* 
that fights a war (by the definition that literally everyone but you 
accepts as fact, not your flip-flopping ambiguous term). States *declare* 
war on *behalf* of a country. If you can't understand that the US 
government is a representation of the country (as all things are decided by 
votes), you are truly the most ignorant person I have ever had the 
displeasure of talking to.

*"Slaughter of Iraqi children"* lmao, that cements it. Make sure you get 
your daily spoonful of media propaganda!

Again, as you still fail to understand (I'm just joking you obviously do, 
you're just being obstinate because you can't bear losing), states are *REPRESENTATIONS 
OF THE PEOPLE*. As you, with your poor literary skills failed to read: "be 
it resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States 
of America in Congress assembled, That the state of war between the United 
States and the Imperial German Government"

I'll break this simple statement down for you, even though you will likely 
again try to muddle it with some ambiguous garbage:
*be it resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United 
States of America assembled*
As any person with a fully functioning brain and understanding of 7th grade 
civics can understand, this means that a decision is being made by the 
Congress, the *state* on *behalf* of the *country*. 
*That a state of war between the United States and the Imperial German 
Government*
Quite clearly, a *state of war between the country of the United States and 
the Government of Germany*.
This means that by decision of the *state*, the *country* of the United 
States will go to war with the *government* of Imperial Germany. As by that 
Iraq quote I can clearly tell you don't know the damndest thing about war 
or history and general (I'm still laughing about it to be honest), I will 
clearly define the situation to you. *WE* (I know that rustles your 
jimmies) went to war with the Imperial German  *Government*  to unseat them 
from power as the leaders of the *country* of Germany.

That is as simple as it can be made. There is literally no room for 
misinterpretation. However, I fully trust you to spin some kind of vague 
and ambiguous contest of terms and arguments, that we both know are futile.

But that's OK, some people just don't know how to take a loss.
comments.author: Colin G

comments.text:
+Colin G In your reply, you said that I said countries are *"ONLY"* 
geographical areas. But no where in my responses did I ever say that. I 
said it was *"more or less"* a geographical area, which it is. There is 
obviously more to it than simply a location, as the definition states: it 
is a location ruled or "controlled" by a state. But ultimately, it is a 
location.

Nonetheless, what picture am I suppose to get? You didn't prove or disprove 
anything. States engages in wars. I am not part of the government (the 
people who actually make up its main bureaucracy, creates laws and declare 
wars) or the military (the coercive group of people who actually engages in 
wars). I don't voluntarily support any of them by any means whatsoever. I 
didn't participate in the slaughter of Iraqi children. "We" did not 
simulate a nuclear first strike.

*World War I:*
*be it resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United 
States of America in Congress assembled, That the state of war between the 
United States and the Imperial German Government"*

The senate and house are part of the U.S. government. "Imperial German 
Government" is not a country.
comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.text:
+Alique Williams You are unabashedly the least intelligent person I have 
ever debated. No, I take that back. You know you're wrong. You're 
just trying to scrape some kind of victory by relying entirely on 
technicality and word play. We both know what I mean.

There is little to no difference between those two definitions I provided, 
as they are both correct and explain the same term. Is this not obvious?

Here;s a quick recap:
*You*: "The term 'country' emphasizes the physical dimensions and 
boundaries of a geographical area" "the word 'country' is used to define 
the geographical landmass they live on, and the neighbors they have"
*Me*: "If countries are*only* geographic expanses of land..."
*You*: "Show me exactly in my quote I said that?"

You didn't even care to read your own quotes before replying. Lol, they 
literally say, in plain English, that a country is a geographic area of 
land defined by certain borders. You clearly don't even believe or 
understand your own argument.

After conceding on your ridiculous "definition of a country" phase, you 
said that *"countries don't declare war, states (governments) do"*.
Let's look at some of our past declarations of war, and see whether "The 
United States" or "The Government of the United States" declares war:

War of 1812:
*Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United 
States of America in Congress assembled, That war be and is hereby declared 
to exist between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and the 
dependencies thereof, and the United States of America and their 
territories...*

World War I:
*...be it resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United 
States of America in Congress assembled, That the state of war between the 
United States and the Imperial German Government..."

Just about every single one of our declarations of war follows similar 
lines, but I think you get the picture.

I realize- why am I even arguing with you? You're going to make some 
laughable attempt at an argument before resorting back to your "I didn't do 
this, I didn't do this" rehetoric. It's an empty, misguided, and cheap 
fallacy. Can't wait for your reply.
comments.author: Colin G

comments.text:
+Colin G Lets go through this more slowly.

Me: "A country is, *more or less*, a geographical area. It doesn't conduct 
war."

You: "If countries are *ONLY* geographic expanses of land..."

Show me exactly in my quote I said that? I emphasize the geography part 
because that's what's most important here. Obviously a country is an area 
ruled by a state. But ultimately, it is still an area.

Here is the definition from a link you share: "an area of land that is 
controlled by its own government"

Here's another: "an area of land that forms an independent political unit 
with its own government"

What's the difference? Nonetheless, countries don't declare war. States do 
(more precisely, the government). Heads of states make and conduct war 
against other states. I am not part of the government, or any other 
bureaucracy which makes up the state. I don't wage war. "We" didn't invade 
Iraq. I did not win a cold war. I, nor the country, engaged in a military 
exercise, which simulated a nuclear first strike. The military isn't the 
country.

By the way, where did I lie about a source lol?
comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.text:
+Alique Williams My ego? Not that of the person who is telling me that I 
will "run away" from their oh-so-glorious speech? Before you continue to be 
obstinate and ignorant, I will debunk your incomplete and dishonest opinion 
of a country.

If countries are *ONLY* geographic expanses of land, I guess the Gobi 
desert is a country. The Arctic? The Sahara? No? Well what is it that 
makes, say, Canada different than the Arctic circle? It has a culture, 
people, a government, laws, trade, language, and many more things than your 
idea of a "country" does not have.

Your concept of a country is obviously flawed, but at least Wikipedia 
agrees with you right?
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Country: *"A country is a region identified as 
a distinct entity in political geography. A country may be an independent 
sovereign state or one that is occupied by another state, as a 
non-sovereign or formerly sovereign political division, or a geographic 
region associated with sets of previously independent or differently 
associated peoples with distinct political characteristics. Regardless of 
the physical geography, in the modern internationally accepted legal 
definition as defined by the League of Nations in 1937 and reaffirmed by 
the United Nations in 1945, a resident of a country is subject to the 
independent exercise of legal jurisdiction"*

You bring one source to the argument (an open and relatively unregulated 
website I might add) and *it literally contradicts everything you have to 
say*. You unabashedly *lied about your own source*. I cannot deny that is 
the most pathetic reference failure I have ever encountered in debate.

But as I said, Wikipedia isn't the most credible source, right? Does anyone 
else support me, with actual credentials?
http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/country
http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/country
http://dictionary.cambridge.org/us/dictionary/american-english/country
http://www.macmillandictionary.com/dictionary/british/country
You could say that. Every source I found supported my argument, but I doubt 
you've even read this far, so I'll only show you these four.

As you can see, not a *single* source supports your argument *(not even 
your own)*. Obviously my logic cannot penetrate your thick skull, so I hope 
these professionals, experts, and renowned university professors can. 
Otherwise, I can do no more.
comments.author: Colin G

comments.text:
+Colin G Before I begin, I know you will reach a point where you will 
simply run away and stop responding. But before you do, let me tell you at 
that it's actually your ego which is preventing you from comprehending.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Country

What you described above is not the definition of a country. Perhaps you're 
confused with the term nation state?

1) *"the term 'country' emphasizes the physical dimensions and boundaries 
of a geographical area."* 

2) *"the word “country” is used to define the geographical landmass that 
they live on, and the neighbors that they have.*"

Those are the definition of country. Nonetheless, states are the actual 
entities who conduct war, not the countries they occupy. It is states who 
wield armed conflict against other states around the world. I am not a part 
of or included in the functioning of the state, nor are my parents.
comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.text:
+Alique Williams
+Alique Williams A country is NOT a geographical area. It is a combination 
of that area, it's people, it's customs, it's laws, and it's government. Do 
you not consider yourself one of America's people? If not, then you are 
exempt. I never said that you were involved in the functioning of the state.


We did invade Iraq. You and I didn't, but "we" as in the United States of 
America, did. Literally everyone *but* you accepts that terminology. You're 
trying to use some kind of altered word play to exploit a technicality. 
Technically, you are correct, but logically, realistically, and 
functionally, so am I. This argument is a waste of time based on a childish 
exploitation of a technicality. Seriously. It's sad.
comments.author: Colin G

comments.text:
+Alique Williams A country is NOT a geographical area. It is a combination 
of that area, it's people, it's customs, it's laws, and it's government. Do 
you not consider yourself one of America's people? If not, than you are 
exempt. I never said that you were involved in the functioning of the state.

We did invade Iraq. You and I didn't, but "we" as in the United States of 
America, did. Literally everyone *but* you accepts that terminology. You're 
trying to use some kind of altered word play to exploit a technicality. 
Technically, you are correct, but logically, realistically, and 
functionally, so am I. This argument is a waste of time based on a childish 
exploitation of a technicality. Seriously. It's sad.
comments.author: Colin G

comments.text:
+Colin G A country is, more or less, a geographical area. It doesn't 
conduct war. *Sovereign* states do. Me simply living in one area does not 
mean I am involved in the functioning of the state which occupies it. 
That's ultimately what I'm getting at.

Let me ask you this: Did "we" invade Iraq? Let me guess, the country "we 
are a part of" did right? Wrong. What if I was living in Iraq during the 
start of the war, then moved to NY? When could you then say "we" invaded it?
comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.text:
+Alique Williams Your lack of basic comprehension of the subject is 
astounding. You truly have no understanding of this subject, or basic 
terminology at all. When he says "*we*" he means our country. AMERICA. *THE 
COUNTRY WE ARE A PART OF*. I'm not going to speak with you any further, for 
I am seriously concerned about your daily functioning in the real world and 
your comprehension of information. I hope any passersby who read this 
conversation maintained their current level of brain cells. Good day.
comments.author: Colin G

comments.text:
+Colin G I am fearful of an exploding Sun, but I am not involved in it's 
chemical functioning.

Let me show you all the phrases from Green I object to:

"...the US trying to expand its markets. By the way, is exactly what *'we'* 
were doing"

"...*'we'* won the cold war"

"...when *'we'* forgot the give the Russians the heads up that *'we'* were 
doing some war games, which made it look like *'we'* had launched a first 
strike. *'Our'* bad."

"Frankly, all of *'our'* attempts to stabilize latin America..."

Do you see? Me, nor my parents, were involved in those events. There is no 
"we". "We" didn't win a cold war because "we" don't conduct military 
operations of any state or are part of it.
comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.text:
+Alique Williams As I said, the Cold War did not revolve around any one 
event, only specific beginning and end years. You were a child of the new 
generation, born to carry on a lifestyle of fear and paranoia or one of 
freedom and peace. You were the reason your parents (and country) were 
afraid, and you were an inspiration to everyone involved, and literally the 
last generation of the Cold War.
comments.author: Colin G

comments.text:
+Colin G Right. So what are you saying? I was not involved in any event in 
the entire cold war.
comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.text:
+Alique Williams Of course we were not involved in those specific events. 
If you actually read my post, you would know that the Cold War was not tied 
to any one event. JFK wasn't involved with the fall of the Berlin wall, but 
was he involved in the Cold War?
comments.author: Colin G

comments.text:
+Colin G Not sure exactly what you're talking about. The quotes I wrote 
were of Green in the video. He spoke of specific events he claimed "we" 
were involved in. I am saying "we" were not involved in them. I was not 
involved in any simulated nuclear first strike.
comments.author: Alique Williams

comments.text:
+Alique Williams
Do not strawman me. The Cold War was, quoted from Oxford University, "A 
state of political hostility between countries characterized by threats, 
propaganda, and other measures short of open warfare, in particular". It 
was not a single or series of static events.
comments.author: Colin G

comments.author: Webster

comments.text:
Here is the takeaway folks. Communism started out in Russia in 1917, and it 
spread poverty. Capitalism in America allowed the rich  to keep their money 
and for the formation of private enterprise and huge "evil" corporations. 
It reduced poverty. In spite of having more people, the USSR's GDP was less 
than half of America's and their per capita GDP was far less than half of 
America's. According to a former Soviet planner and economist Yuri Maltsev 
(look him up), Soviet poverty was appalling compared to America's, and at 
the same time that Bill Gates and Steve Jobs were bringing the personal 
computer to individuals in America in the 1980s, Soviets had been reduced 
to a society of beggars and scavengers.

Taking money away from all of the rich and giving it to all of the poor to 
make sure that everyone was absolutely equal created devastating poverty. 
The poor in the USSR were more than three decades behind the poor in 
America in terms of income, healthcare, and what amenities they had, like 
cars, refrigerators etc. America was to the right of the USSR, and this 
economic freedom allowed for the so-called "trickle down" effect to expand 
the economy and help the poor. Poverty was off the charts in the Soviet 
Union compared to America. When rich people could keep their money, they 
expanded their businesses and hired more poor people, reducing their 
poverty level and increasing their standard of living. It is the difference 
of giving a man a fish (communism) or teaching him to fish (capitalism). 
There was more wealth inequality in America, but the poor did better in 
America compared to the poor of the USSR, where there was more equality of 
income.

This made the Soviet system rickety and prone to a revolution. Reagan 
outspent the Soviets in the military sphere, and it bankrupted them. The 
Soviet military couldn't respond when revolutions broke out in Eastern 
Europe, and capitalism toppled communism in Eastern Europe and then in the 
USSR. The whole Soviet system was held in place by the Soviet military, 
When it was bankrupted, the USSR collapsed. A similar left wing economic 
system can be seen playing out in Venezuela today. There are serious 
shortages in basic necessities, and the people are revolting, demanding a 
right wing economic system, although America is not engaging Venezuela in a 
competitive arms race. There are also Soviet-like systems in place in Cuba 
and North Korea. These places have severe shortages of food and other 
necessities.﻿
comments.author: RonaldReaganRocks1

comments.text:

comments.author: william97able

comments.text:
Even though the Cold War of the 80's was in some ways a very dangerous 
period, there are some things I miss about it.  Back then we had a very 
high sense of nationalism, patriotism, and loyalty.  We could legitimately 
claim the moral high ground over our enemies.

-On an early episode of The Simpsons, a bunch of baseball fans throw 
tomatoes at a speaker for the Springfield Communist Party.

-In an episode of 21 Jump Street, a talk show host (modeled after Morton 
Downey Jr) condemns Captain Fuller by comparing his undercover police 
program to the dictatorship of the Soviet Union.

-In my 10th grade Modern World History Class, the teacher wanted to compare 
and contrast Capitalism and Communism.  When he asked the class the name of 
the American economic system, one student answered, "Freedom?"

Back in the 80s we all knew who the enemy was.  To be told that you were 
not a real American was considered an insult.  Even though we were not 
perfect, we could still claim the moral high ground over Soviet Russia.

Now it is different.  We cannot tell who the enemy is anymore.  Colleges 
ban the American flag in lobbies because it might "offensive" someone. 
 Apartment managers ban the American flag from tenant's units for fear of 
"offending" someone.  American values are censored from public view because 
they are "offensive" to godless atheists.  People who oppose fascism or 
sexual deviancy are labeled as, "hateful bigots".  Traitors who give aid 
and comfort to the enemy are praised for their "diversity" and "equality".

Back in the early 1900s, China had an identity crisis, as they were 
culturally invaded by foreign influences at the expense of their own 
traditional values.  They had the Boxer Rebellion to expel the foreign 
cultural invaders.  We Americans need a modern Boxer Rebellion to expel the 
foreign cultural invaders with their anti-American values.  And fuck 
political correctness.﻿
